message: when you use gr with a motion, it will delete whatever that motion covers, and paste whatever was in your yank register
This is a common patter I don't have an efficient solution for: Got something in my default register, move elsewhere, want to replace a similar line segment ...
if I, say di" because I want to place the yanked text within quotes, I'll loose what I've yanked
will I just have to learn to yank into alternate registers? or is there a simpler way?
There is a much simpler way
took me a while to learn it
awesome plugin that fixes a huge annoyance with vim, imo.
@edanm nice thanks
There's a plugin called ReplaceWithRegister

so for your example, you'd yank something, then do:
gri"
Here's a link: http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2703
which defines a new command: gr (think - go replace)
The built in option is visual mode so like in your example I have something in my register and I want to replace something in quotes with it I type vi"p
@edanm thanks this great :D
The drawback on using the built-in vi"p is that it replaces the default register with the removed content, so you can't repeat the same replace.
@ricobl Yeah, that was my problem with it as well. It is a good option if you're faced with a vanilla vim installation though.
@edanm Sure, I agree!

According to http://tottinge.blogsome.com/use-vim-like-a-pro a register _ is something like /dev/null.
So when you want to delete text without messing what you have now in default register with "_d<motion> and then y your default register in place

I think what I would like to try, is defaulting c to yank to the black hole register, when I go to change text, my next action is almost always to type something, or p from default register - what is the best way to do that, just to remap c to _c?

Using "_ as mentioned by @brabadu is your best bet, but also remember that if you clobber your default register, the contents can still be accessed using "0. Use :reg to see a full list of your registers and their contents.

vmap P "_dp
This maps 'P' in visual mode to delete into the black hole register and paste.
